description: High-level overview of Canadian constitutional law and the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Covers division of powers, Charter structure, Section 1 analysis, remedies, and constitutional supremacy. Educational framework only â€” not legal advice.

topics.title: Constitutional Supremacy
topics.coreDefinition: The Constitution is the supreme law of Canada. Any law inconsistent with it is of no force or effect to the extent of the inconsistency (Constitution Act, 1982, s.52).
frameworkSteps: Identify the challenged law or government action.
quickExamples: A provincial law conflicting with Charter protections may be struck down.
Federal law exceeding division-of-powers authority may be invalid.
commonMistakes: Assuming all unfair laws are unconstitutional.
Ignoring division-of-powers analysis before Charter analysis.

topics.title: Division of Powers (Federal vs Provincial)
topics.coreDefinition: Legislative powers are divided between federal and provincial governments under sections 91 and 92 of the Constitution Act, 1867.
frameworkSteps: Identify the subject matter of legislation.
Classify under federal or provincial head of power.
Apply pith and substance analysis if necessary.
quickExamples: Criminal law falls under federal authority.
Property and civil rights fall under provincial authority.

topics.title: Structure of the Charter
topics.coreDefinition: The Charter protects fundamental freedoms, democratic rights, mobility rights, legal rights, equality rights, and language rights.
frameworkSteps: Determine whether state action is involved.
Apply Section 1 analysis if infringement found.
quickExamples: Section 7 protects life, liberty, and security of the person.
commonMistakes: Assuming Charter applies to private disputes.

topics.title: Section 1 and the Oakes Test
topics.coreDefinition: Even if a Charter right is infringed, the government may justify the limitation under Section 1 if it is reasonable and demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society.
quickExamples: Limits on speech may be upheld if proportional and narrowly tailored.
commonMistakes: Assuming any infringement is automatically invalid.

topics.title: Charter Remedies (Section 24)
topics.coreDefinition: Section 24(1) allows courts to grant appropriate and just remedies for Charter breaches. Section 24(2) may exclude evidence obtained in violation of rights.
frameworkSteps: Apply exclusion test under section 24(2) if applicable.
quickExamples: Evidence excluded if admission would bring administration of justice into disrepute.

topics.title: Notwithstanding Clause (Section 33)
topics.coreDefinition: Section 33 permits Parliament or provincial legislatures to override certain Charter rights temporarily.
frameworkSteps: Determine if legislation invokes section 33 explicitly.
Confirm five-year limitation and renewal requirements.
quickExamples: Section 33 cannot override democratic or mobility rights.
commonMistakes: Assuming override applies automatically without express declaration.
Believing all rights can be overridden.

notes: Supports high-level Charter and constitutional analysis.
Requires state action to engage Charter rights.
Encourage consultation with qualified counsel for case-specific matters.
